problem.tex: Let $\Omega$ be a region and take a loop $\gamma:[0,1]\to\Omega$. Let $a\in\Omega\setminus\gamma$. Recall the winding number is \[n(\gamma;a)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_\gamma\frac{1}{z-a}dz.\] If $b$ is in the same path component as $a$ in $\Omega\setminus\gamma$, show that $n(\gamma;a)=n(\gamma;b)$.

solution.tex: Let $p:[0,1]\to\Omega\setminus\gamma$ be a path with $p(0)=a$ and $p(1)=b$. We want to look at the integral \[\int_\gamma\frac{1}{z-p(s)}dz.\] We will do a change of variables. Let $\gamma_s(t)=\gamma(t)-p(s)+a$. Note $\gamma_s(t)$ never hits $a$ for any $s,t$ because $p$ never hits $\gamma$. Also $\gamma_s'=\gamma'$ and \[\int_\gamma\frac{1}{z-p_s}dz=\int_0^1\frac{\gamma'(t)}{\gamma(t)-p_s}dt=\int_0^1\frac{\gamma_s'(t)}{\gamma_s(t)-a}dt=\int_{\gamma_s}\frac{1}{z-a}dz.\] We have constructed a path homotopy from $\gamma_0$ to $\gamma_1$, where the image of the homotopy lies in $\mathbb{C}\setminus\{a\}$. Thus, by Cauchy's integral theorem, \[\int_{\gamma_0}\frac{1}{z-a}dz=\int_{\gamma_1}\frac{1}{z-a}dz.\] Note that $\gamma_0$ is just $\gamma$, so the left hand side is $(2\pi i)n(\gamma;a)$. The right hand side is \[\int_0^1\frac{\gamma_1'(t)}{\gamma(t)-p(1)+a-a}dt=\int_0^1\frac{\gamma'(t)}{\gamma(t)-b}dt=\int_\gamma\frac{1}{z-b}dz=(2\pi i)n(\gamma;b).\] Thus $n(\gamma;a)=n(\gamma;b)$.
